title: Jurgen Klopp and Mohamed Salah gear up to break Manchester United ducks
text:
Jurgen Klopp has warned Mo Salah to expect some rough treatment as both men try to break their Manchester United ducks and make Premier League history.

Salah, the country’s top scorer in the last two seasons, has never scored against United and was substituted during last season’s goalless draw while Klopp is still seeking his first victory at Old Trafford.

Victory for Liverpool would be their 18th Premier League win in a row to equal the record set by Pep Guardiola’s Manchester City in his first title season.

Jurgen Klopp is looking to pick up his first win at Old Trafford when Liverpool play United

Salah is expected to recover from a knock he received against Leicester a fortnight ago but can expect another stern physical examination against United whose full-backs Ashley Young and Luke Shaw have targeted him in the past.

‘If someone had told me that he (Salah) had never scored against United, I would have said 'really?' said Klopp.

‘I suppose the more you go without scoring against an opponent there may be one moment when you start scoring.

‘There is a reason for these kinds of stories, just like our history and stats against United away, such as the stadium or the intensity of the game, stuff like that.

‘Yes, it is a big test and sometimes there will be the “old school” challenges and you have to be ready for them. That is how it is.’

Mo Salah has also never scored a goal against Manchester United in his career

Klopp’s own record away to United is poor though he did gain a draw there in his first season to knock Louis van Gaal’s side out of the Europa League.

Liverpool were beaten 2-1 in the league two seasons ago but gained a point in a goalless draw last season.

‘We are getting closer. If there had been a winner it would have been us,’ said the Liverpool boss.

‘We have to be ready to try to use the atmosphere there, stay calm in the right moments and pass at the right moments. To do that you have to grow as a team and we have grown as a team.

‘When I first came here and we went to Old Trafford it was difficult to face that situation. Nobody expected us to win but now the situation has changed. We expect - whoever we are or wherever we go - a chance to win the game.

‘We have to go there and play the best football we can play, with the biggest ‘balls’, being ready for each challenge, fighting for every ball, all that stuff.’

Klopp said it is surprising that the free-scoring Salah hasn't managed to score against United

Klopp’s biggest selection poser is in midfield with 33-year-old James Milner staking a claim after his rest during the international break.

Milner is reaping the rewards of retiring from England duty and was given a week off from Liverpool’s training ground at Melwood to tick over with a specially-devised training programme.

‘The boys not involved on international duty have a week away from Melwood. But they have a proper training plan, but not football work,’ revealed Klopp.

‘They have to write every day when they have a session. It makes no sense to have a session with three players and five coaches!

‘Having that break (from international football) is the perfect situation for a footballer at that age so Milly was very smart when he made that decision.

Klopp's biggest selection dilemma is whether to include James Milner from the start

‘It was a conscious decision for him to think what was needed. He has made a lot of smart decisions in his life and that was just another one. For England everything is OK, and for him and us, it’s all good.’

It’s in Klopp’s nature to relish the big stage and being centre-stage at Old Trafford in front of 76,000 people will take him back to the huge Schalke-Dortmund derbies from his time in Germany.

‘Emotionally, there was nothing bigger than that. I don’t compare it (to United-Liverpool), I only know how it feels so it is the same size.

‘Maybe in the world, more people watch United against Liverpool but in Germany Dortmund Schalke is a game, everyone has a chance, we watch it because of the emotion and everybody knows about the rivalry.

‘I don't have to compare them. I only know how it feels and how it is in a game and how difficult it is of course. Still, you have to find a way to bring your plan on the pitch and make it more likely to win a game more than not and that's what we try.

The Liverpool boss may look to rely on Milner's experience in a potentially difficult atmosphere

‘One of the biggest stories of my career was that the fourth matchday when I came to Dortmund was the derby. We had started quite well in the season, I think, and were 3-0 down at home at half-time.

‘Second-half starts, Kevin Kuranyi, striker from Schalke, is in a one-on-one situation with the goalkeeper and if he scores the fourth we are done.

‘He didn't, we equalised and we played 3-3. It felt like we won the game and each time Schalke was much better than we were so it was a big mark when people started thinking this team could be something special in future.

‘I know what kind of signal a game like this can be so that's why I know what United tries to do.’
description: Jurgen Klopp has warned Mo Salah to expect some rough treatment as both men try to break their Manchester United ducks  and make Premier League history.
authors: Joe Bernstein For The Mail On Sunday
